CDFglobalAttributes.Project: STSP Cluster>Solar Terrestrial Science Programmes, Cluster
CDFglobalAttributes.TEXT:
Cluster Ion Spectrometry.
The CIS (Cluster Ion Spectrometry) experiment is a comprehensive
ionic plasma spectrometry package onboard the Cluster spacecraft,
capable of obtaining full three-dimentional ion distributions
(about 0 to 40 keV/e) with a time resolution of one spacecraft spin (4 sec)
and with mass-per-charge composition determination.
The CIS package consists of two different instruments,
a time-of-flight ion Composition and Distribution Function analyser (CODIF, or CIS-1)
and a Hot Ion Analyser (HIA, or CIS-2).
CDFglobalAttributes.MISSION_DESCRIPTION:
The aim of the Cluster mission is to study small-scale structures of the magnetosphere 
and its environment in three dimensions. To achieve this, Cluster is constituted of four 
identical spacecraft that will flight in a tetrahedral configuration. The separation distances 
between the spacecraft will be varied between ~3 km and 67 000 km, according to the 
key scientific regions.
CDFglobalAttributes.MISSION_REFERENCES: The Cluster and Phoenix Missions>Cluster project and instrument teams>Space Sci. Rev. 79, Nos. 1-2, 1997

CDFglobalAttributes.Experiment_description:
Cluster Ion Spectrometry.
The CIS (Cluster Ion Spectrometry) experiment is a comprehensive
ionic plasma spectrometry package onboard the Cluster spacecraft,
capable of obtaining full three-dimentional ion distributions
(about 0 to 40 keV/e) with a time resolution of one spacecraft spin (4 sec)
and with mass-per-charge composition determination.
The CIS package consists of two different instruments,
a time-of-flight ion Composition and Distribution Function analyser (CODIF, or CIS-1)
and a Hot Ion Analyser (HIA, or CIS-2).

CDFglobalAttributes.Instrument_description:
CIS COmposition DIstribution Function analyser on Cluster C4.
CODIF consists of two sections, each with a 180Â° field of view
A high-sensitivity (HS) side and a low-sensitivity (LS) side.
The HS side is best adapted for low-flux populations, as for example
in the magnetosphere or the upstreaming populations in the foreshock region.
The LS side is best adapted for high-flux populations, as for example
in the magnetosheath and in the solar wind (solar wind beam), where the HS side can saturate.
The operation of each sensitivity side is mutually exclusive.
cf. the CIS User Guide for details
CDFglobalAttributes.Dataset_description:
He+ density (with standard devitation), which is
improved/corrected by removing estimated contamination of
H+ spillover into the He+ mass channel
